Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Dynamic Needle Tip Positioning and Long-Axis In-Plane Techniques for Internal Jugular Vein Cannulation

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at AIIMS, Raipur, involving 100 patients aged 18-70 years undergoing elective surgery requiring IJV cannulation.

Participants.evidence: involving 100 patients aged 18-70 years undergoing elective surgery requiring IJV cannulation.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the DNTP group (n=50) or the LAIP group (n=50)

Objective.evidence: This study aims to compare the first-pass success rate of IJV cannulation using the dynamic needle tip positioning (DNTP) technique versus the long-axis in-plane (LAIP) approach.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the first-pass success rate, measured immediately after the procedure.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the DNTP group (n=50) or the LAIP group (n=50) using a computer-generated random number table with a block size of 4. Randomisation was concealed using opaque envelopes

Number_Randomised.evidence: involving 100 patients aged 18-70 years undergoing elective surgery requiring IJV cannulation. Participants were randomly assigned to either the DNTP group (n=50) or the LAIP group (n=50)

Number_Analysed.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the DNTP group (n=50) or the LAIP group (n=50)

Result_Outcome.evidence: The first-pass success rate was significantly higher in the DNTP group (96%) compared to the LAIP group (76%), with a relative risk of 1.67 (95% CI, 0.039-0.707; p=0.008).

Harms.evidence: No complications such as pneumothorax or hematoma were observed in either group.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial was registered under CTRI/2022/02/039907
